contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=July 2010}} {{Infobox MLB player |name=Jared Sandberg |image=<!-- only free-content images are allowed for depicting living people. Non-free and "fair use" images, promo photos, etc., will be deleted - see [[WP:NONFREE]] --> |position=[[Third baseman]] |bats=Right |throws=Right |birth_date={{Birth date and age|1978|3|2}}<BR>[[Olympia, Washington]] |death_date= |debutdate=August 7 |debutyear=2001 |debutteam=Tampa Bay Devil Rays |finaldate=September 26 |finalyear=2003 |finalteam=Tampa Bay Devil Rays |stat1label=[[Batting average]] |stat1value=.221 |stat2label=[[Home run]]s |stat2value=25 |stat3label=[[Run batted in|Runs batted in]] |stat3value=92 |teams=<nowiki></nowiki> * [[Tampa Bay Rays|Tampa Bay Devil Rays]] ({{By|2001}}â€“{{By|2003}}) }} '''Jared Lawrence Sandberg''' (born March 2, 1978 in [[Olympia, Washington]]) is a former [[Major League Baseball]] [[third baseman]] for the [[Tampa Bay Rays|Tampa Bay Devil Rays]]. The nephew of former [[Chicago Cubs]] second baseman [[Ryne Sandberg]], he is currently the [[Manager (baseball)|manager]] of the Class-A level [[Bowling Green Hot Rods]] in the Rays organization. Sandberg was born in [[Olympia, Washington]]. In {{By|2002}}, Sandberg showed potential to hit for power, hitting 18 [[home run]]s in 102 games with the Devil Rays. However, his difficulties hitting for [[Batting average|average]] prevented him from spending a full season in the major leagues. In {{By|2005}}, Sandberg played with the [[Portland Sea Dogs]], Double-A affiliate of the [[Boston Red Sox]]. Sandberg started the {{By|2006}} season with the [[Houston Astros]] Double-A affiliate [[Corpus Christi Hooks]]. He played mainly third base, but struggled to hit for average. In his final game for the Hooks, he broke out of an 0-for-26 slump with a home run. The following day, he was released to make room for a player to come off the [[disabled list]]. Sandberg signed with the [[Cleveland Indians]] and was assiged to the Double-A [[Akron Aeros]]. In {{By|2007}}, Sandberg signed with the [[Kansas City Royals]], and was assigned to play for the Double-A [[Wichita Wranglers]]. He retired after the 2007 season and took a job as the hitting coach for the Single-A [[Hudson Valley Renegades]] in the Tampa Bay Rays organization. After the {{By|2008}} season, he became the manager of the Rookie level [[Princeton Rays]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oursportscentral.com/services/releases/?id=3754277|title=Princeton Rays Announce 2009 Coaches|date=19 December 2008|publisher=oursportscentral.com|accessdate=14 July 2010}}</ref> In the 2013 season, he became the manager of the Single-A [[Bowling Green Hot Rods]] in the Tampa Rays organization. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Baseballstats|br=s/sandbja01}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Sandberg, Jared | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = American baseball player | DATE OF BIRTH = 1978-03-02 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sandberg, Jared}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Baseball players from Washington (state)]] [[Category:Major League Baseball third basemen]] [[Category:Tampa Bay Devil Rays players]] [[Category:Akron Aeros players]] [[Category:Hudson Valley Renegades players]] [[Category:Charleston RiverDogs players]] [[Category:Orlando Rays players]] [[Category:Durham Bulls players]] [[Category:Portland Sea Dogs players]] [[Category:Wichita Wranglers players]] [[Category:Somerset Patriots players]] [[Category:Minor league baseball managers]]
